title: Civil servants protest outside PM office
description:
(26 Sep 2017) LEADIN:
Civil servants in Lebanon have gone on strike in a row over wages.
The government is struggling to fund a recently agreed pay rise. 
STORYLINE:
Hundreds of civil servants crowd the streets outside the Prime Minister's office.
They are on strike to pressure the government to pay them recently approved wage hikes amid a new crisis over how to finance them.
The police are out in force- many in riot gear - in case of trouble at the demonstration.
Hanna Gharib, Head of Lebanese Communist Party, says the protests must "escalated".
"People should go on the streets not only for the pay raise and the taxes but for the entire social and economic issues in the country," he says.
He lists education, medication, electricity and water issues as the major problems.
Teachers hold signs aloft demanding to be "happy again".
Hoda Ghazi says those in the profession are no longer able to "live with dignity". 
She says salaries are so low that teachers are not able to educate their students.
The strike has left classrooms empty.
But the Cabinet has convened to discuss the ways to finance the new wages.
The bill is estimated to be 800 million US dollars. 
The law improving the wages, which had been in the works for years, was passed earlier this summer. 
But the Constitutional Council earlier this week revoked a tax law to finance the bill, saying it violated the constitution.
The decision left the government scrambling for ways to finance the wage bill, amid pressure from public servants who expected their new salaries this month.
Melhem Riyashi, the Lebanese Information Minister, says the law has been discussed "in depth" today.
"The discussion is not over and will be continued on Thursday in a session at the Presidency Palace headed by the president,             hoping that the law will be approved by the parliament," he continues.
So it will be at least two more days before civil servants can be confident of an increase in their pay packets.
